SENT.plain: Our specific aim was to assess how thrombophilic exogenous estrogens interacted with heritable thrombophilias leading to non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) and ischemic stroke
Coagulation measures were performed in a 74 year old patient and her immediate family
The proband had a 47 year history of 9 previous thrombotic episodes, and developed unilateral NAION 4 years after starting estrogen replacement therapy (ERT)

The proband was heterozygous for two thrombophilic gene mutations (G20210A prothrombin gene, platelet glycoprotein IIIa P1A1/A2 polymorphism), and homozygous for the C677T mutation in the methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene
Of 238 normal controls, none had these 3 gene mutations together
The proband's mother and brother had deep venous thrombosis (DVT)
The proband's brother, sister, nephew, daughter, and two granddaughters were homozygous for the C677T MTHFR mutation
The proband's brother was heterozygous for the G20210A prothrombin gene mutation

The proband's niece was heterozygous for the G20210A prothrombin gene mutation, homozygous for the C677T MTHFR mutation, homozygous for the hypofibrinolytic 4G polymorphism of the plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) gene, and heterozygous for the platelet glycoprotein IIIa P1A1/A2 polymorphism
Of 238 normal controls, none had the niece's combination of 4 gene mutations
When ERT-mediated thrombophilia was superimposed on the proband's heritable thrombophilias, unilateral ischemic optic neuropathy developed, her tenth thrombotic event over a 5 decade period
When estrogen-progestin oral contraceptives were given to the proband's niece, she had an ischemic stroke at age 22

Exogenous estrogen-mediated thrombophilia superimposed on heritable thrombophilia and hypofibrinolysis is associated with arterial and venous thrombi, and appears to be a preventable, and potentially reversible etiology for ischemic optic neuropathy and ischemic stroke
